docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich announced legislation that would make the state the first in the nation to offer comprehensive health insurance for all children. Families of many of the 253,000 children in the state who lack health insurance earn too much money to qualify for state programs but not enough to pay for private insurance, the governor's office said. The plan would allow families to pay adjusted rates for coverage based on their income. The state would pay the difference between that and the actual cost. The state expects to save money by having a case management program focused on providing preventative care, to reduce emergency care and hospitalizations. The coverage would include prescription drugs, mental health services, doctor and hospital visits and dental and vision care. The legislation will be considered later this month. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Bill Offers Health Insurance For Children

docs.abstract: Gov Rod R Blagojevich announces legislation that would make Illinois first state to offer comprehensive health insurance for children; plan would allow families to pay adjusted rates based on income with state paying difference (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: There was less resentment of my Tuesday column on the courts than I had expected. But some readers did hone in on precisely the issue that I have misgivings about in my own argument -- protection of minority rights. As Joy wrote, "I understand and agree in principle with what you are saying about how liberals should pursue social justice through democratic processes rather than through the courts, but it begs the question, what about the egregious wrongs perpetrated by the majority in this country? Just because there is a political will to discriminate against any number of minorities does not mean that those injustices should be permitted until the huge amount of resources are gathered necessary to change that public opinion. Judicial intervention to remedy injustice, whether a majority agrees or not, is intrinsic to basic human rights.

docs.lead_paragraph: For a few days this week, a piece of the old New Orleans came back to life: the Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra met, rehearsed and played music together for the first time since Hurricane Katrina scattered them like a spray of 16th notes. Traveling from around the country, the musicians gathered here as guests of the Nashville Symphony Orchestra for a concert in their benefit. There were hugs and swapped evacuation stories and, above all, a sense of normality, even if fleeting. Amid the chaos of their lives, they found order on a stage and in a musical score.

headline.main: New Orleans and Nashville Get Together to Make Classical Music

docs.abstract: Members of Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra, traveling from around country, meet, rehearse and play music together for first time since Hurricane Katrina as guests of Nashville Symphony Orchestra for concert in Nashville for their benefit; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Musicians from the Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra gathered this week as guests of the Nashville Symphony Orchestra for a concert in their benefit.

docs.lead_paragraph: GLENN FERRIS never exercised. He didn't need to. As a telephone installer and repairman, he kept active, climbing telephone poles and shimmying under houses to rig wires. When he retired at 52, he cut lawns and clipped hedges for neighbors in Pasadena, Calif. But as the years passed, Mr. Ferris, now 78, slowed down. He began to fear, as he put it, ''the rocking chair coming to get me.''

headline.main: Moving to a 'Don't Grow Old Program'

docs.snippet: A growing number of older Americans are discovering the benefits of exercise.

docs.lead_paragraph: Eddy Curry officially became a member of the Knicks about 6 p.m. Eastern time Tuesday, bringing with him all of the uncertainty and the medical issues that caused the Chicago Bulls to let him go. Curry is one of the most talented young big men in the N.B.A. and, at 22, has his best years ahead of him. He also has an irregular heartbeat and may be predisposed to a heart condition that has proved fatal in other athletes. It was that fear, and Curry's reluctance to take a genetic test to clarify matters, that prompted Chicago to trade him to the Knicks for a package of lesser players and draft picks.

headline.main: Curry Faces Tests to Evaluate Risk Factor

docs.snippet: Eddy Curry has officially become a member of the Knicks, bringing with him all of the medical worries that caused the Chicago Bulls to let him go.

byline.original: By HOWARD BECK; Liz Robbins contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Suddenly, just about everyone in the relatively obscure Gulf Coast Congressional delegation has jumped to the top of the A-list on Capitol Hill. The lawmakers are swamped with invitations to meet a variety of individuals and groups, as a parade of representatives for the regional hospitals, farms, fisheries, universities, school districts and credit unions implore them for help in obtaining shares of the billions of dollars in federal aid that Congress has set aside to rebuild after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita.

headline.main: Gulf Coast Lawmakers in Spotlight as Aid Requests Pour In

docs.abstract: Relatively obscure members of Gulf Coast's Congressional delegation jump to Capitol Hill's A-list, swamped with invitations to meet with representatives of special interests looking for share of billions of dollars in hurricane relief funds; lawmakers like Mississippi Democrat Gene Taylor express amazement at newfound access to Pres Bush, Republican leaders and national media; Sens Mary Landrieu and David Vitter shop list of needs that would cost $250 billion, on top of more than $60 billion already approved by Congress (M)
docs.snippet: Suddenly, just about everyone in the relatively obscure Gulf Coast Congressional delegation has jumped to the top of the A-list on Capitol Hill.

docs.lead_paragraph: Delphi, the nation's largest supplier of auto parts, is prepared to file for bankruptcy as early as this week, lining up lawyers and consultants in preparation for what would be the domestic auto industry's largest filing in recent times. Whether Robert S. Miller, Delphi's chief executive for three months, actually goes through with it remains to be seen. Mr. Miller has said publicly that he will file for bankruptcy by Oct. 17 at the latest, when bankruptcy laws change, unless General Motors, Delphi's former parent, and the United Automobile Workers union agree to what would be a multibillion-dollar bailout. The parties have been conducting discussions for months.
docs.abstract: Delphi, auto parts supplier, is prepared to file for bankruptcy within days, as its chief executive of three months, Robert S Miller, has threatened to do unless General Motors, its former parent, and United Automobile Workers union agree to what would be multibillion-dollar bailout; bankruptcy filing would be painful for GM because it agreed under terms of spinoff to provide medical and pension benefits to Delphi retirees if company went bankrupt before 2007 (M)
docs.snippet: Delphi is prepared to file for bankruptcy as early as this week, in what would be the domestic auto industry's largest filing in recent times.

byline.original: By DANNY HAKIM; Jeremy W. Peters contributed reporting from Detroit for this article, and Mary Williams Walsh from New York

docs.lead_paragraph: In a country that cherishes the names of the dead, reads them aloud, engraves them in stone and stitches them into quilts, it is odd that Hurricane Katrina's victims remain, more than a month later, largely anonymous. There has been no accounting of their age, sex and race, nor of how they died or where they were found. As for how they lived, it is difficult to find even a Web site paying tribute to individual victims. With 972 deaths confirmed and the search for bodies declared complete, the state has released only 61 bodies and made the names of only 32 victims public.

headline.main: Weeks Later, Most Storm Victims Lie Unnamed

docs.abstract: Hurricane Katrina's victims remain largely anonymous more than month after disaster, with no accounting of their age, sex and race or how they died and where they were found; photo; Louisiana has 972 confirmed deaths but has released only 61 bodies and named only 32; Mississippi by contrast has identified 196 of its 221 dead; Louisiana officials link delays to autopsies in criminal investigations, disruption of hurricane Rita and deterioration of bodies; New Orleans coroner Frank Minyard says he awaits FEMA trailer to house volunteer pathologists from around country, but critics say state is not releasing even bodies with obvious identification, demanding fingerprints, dental or DNA matches rather than tattoos, driver's licenses and physical characteristics accepted by Mississippi; authorities elsewhere clearly document victims among evacuees; frustrated families are forced to wait for funerals, insurance claims and wills; Louisiana emergency medical director Dr Louis Cataldie defends efforts (M)
docs.snippet: In a country that cherishes the names of the dead, it is odd that Hurricane Katrina's victims remain largely anonymous.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lots of comments on my medical column on Sunday. Paul from Hamilton, Ontario writes: "The Canadian health system is broken too...So someone like me can't find a doctor unless he/she knows the right people. So new immigrants in Canada --and there are a lot of us -- may not be much better off than in the U.S."

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof is rightly concerned about the 45 million Americans who do not have health insurance. But a single-payer system like Canada's is not the only way to address the issue of the uninsured.

headline.main: Can't We Do Better on Health Care?

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Nicholas D. Kristof is rightly concerned about the 45 million Americans who do not have health insurance. But a single-payer system like Canada's is not the only way to address the issue of the uninsured.
